_exec_summary.SummaryText:
U.S. Venture recognizes Safety Management as an essential element in providing a safe and secure place of employment for our associates as well as those people who  interact with our operations. Therefore, creating a safe work environment is extremely important. The corporate core values championed by our President, embraced by our Senior Leadership Team, encouraged by our Managers/Supervisors and pledged to our associates are: a) Caring Relationships, b) Entrepreneurial Spirit, c) Strategic Foresight, and d) High Performance. These 4 core values support our Safety and Health philosophy and management efforts. Interpersonal communications, problem solving, planning, and safety achievement have a direct relationship with the core values when applied to safety training, hazard assessment/investigation, post accident/incident recovery and generating solutions to potential risk exposures. U.S. Venture integrates Safety expectations as a part of Manager/Supervisors' responsibilities in order to create a meaningful daily presence during all work activity. Providing a safe work environment, reinforcing safe behaviors, and achieving meaningful safety results is a shared responsibility. Safety improvements, communication and recommendations from associates are critical to the productivity and success of U.S. Venture.



The U.S. Venture, Inc. - U.S. Oil Madison South Terminal (facility) is a bulk petroleum terminal that stores and distributes millions of gallons of refined petroleum products, including gasoline, diesel oil, denatured ethanol, biodiesel and fuel additives annually.  Three 30 thousand-gallon butane storage tanks (7, 8, and 9), butane blending equipment, and a rail butane delivering system was installed so that butane could be blended into gasoline.  Additionally, propane may be brought in via railcar, unloaded utilizing the butane rail system, temporarily stored in Tank 9, and shipped out via transport.  Also, two 30 thousand-gallon and one 45 thousand-gallon

propane storage tanks (20 21, and 22) and a rail propane delivering system was installed so that propane can be loaded or unloaded via truck.  The quantity of butane and propane that is stored onsite exceeds the 10,000 pound threshold quantities, thus subjecting the facility to RMP requirements. 



The facility complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)#58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal (including OSHA's Process Safety Management Regulation), state, and local laws/codes (including the State of Wisconsin's Department of Safety and Professional Services).  If a fire emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the McFarland Fire Department by calling 911, (distance to closest fire station from terminal is 1.5 miles by road) which may trigger involvement by Dane County Emergency Management, Wisconsin Emergency Management and/or City of Madison Hazardous Materials Team, as necessary.  Each of these Emergency Respnse Departments have and will continue to participate in informative tours at the facility that include an overview of the regulated process, the hazards of butane and propane, and the safety systems that are in place. All facility personnel are 40-hour HAZWOPER certified and receive annual refresher hazardous materials training.



Dane County Emergency Management, in the event of a butane or propane related emergency, will activate their Emergency Telephone Notification System. An authorized operator with the County can identify the affected neighborhood or region of the County and record a message that describes the situation and recommends the protective actions residents should take. The Emergency Telephone Notification system will automatically call out to all phone numbers in the County's database within the geographic area and deliver the recorded message.  If phone lines are busy, the system will attempt to redial those numbers a

predetermined number of times to make contact.  If an answering machine picks up the call, the emergency message will be left on the machine.



The Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the butane blending and propane storage systems, including the associated piping, storage vessels and butane/propane rail cars. To date, the facility has not had an accident involving butane or propane which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with the Fire Department and Dane County Emergency Management. 



Efforts to improve system safety include implementing a web based notification system (SmartNotice) to enhance internal and external communication in the event of an emergency.  During an emergency, the notification system can be used to communicate critical information including security threats, fires, and chemical releases to local McFarland businesses, the McFarland Fire Department, and Dane County Local Emergency Planning Committee.



The SmartNotice service will be capable of reaching out to people in minutes.  During an emergency situation, facility trained personnel will be able to send out a notification from the web, app, or call a 24/7 phone number staffed by Emergency Communications Network (ECN), the provider of SmartNotice, who will facilitate sending out the message on U.S. Oil's behalf.  Notifications can be sent via email, text, and/or phone depending on each individual preference.
